title: Exercises: Countries, Nationalities & Verb To Be

items.prompt: Choose the correct question: 'Where ______ you from?'
items.explanation: We use 'are' with the pronoun 'you'.

items.prompt: I am from Spain. I am ______.
items.explanation: Spanish is the nationality for people from Spain.

items.prompt: She ______ from Mexico. She is American.
items.explanation: 'Is not' (or isn't) is the negative form for 'she'.

items.prompt: ______ they from the UK?
items.explanation: We use 'Are' to start a question with 'they'.

items.prompt: He is from Germany. He is ______.
items.explanation: German is the nationality adjective for Germany.

items.prompt: We ______ Russian. We are Polish.
items.explanation: We use 'are not' for the plural pronoun 'we'.

items.prompt: What is the nationality for Japan?
items.explanation: The nationality for Japan is Japanese.

items.prompt: Is your boss French? No, he ______.
items.explanation: The negative short answer for 'he is' is 'No, he is not' (or 'he isn't').

items.prompt: Where ______ your company based?
items.explanation: Your company (it) takes the singular verb 'is'.

items.prompt: They are from France. They speak ______.
items.explanation: People from France speak French.

items.prompt: Select the correct negative sentence:
items.explanation: We place 'not' after the verb 'am' to form the negative.

items.prompt: Is the new client Chinese? Yes, she ______.
items.explanation: The affirmative short answer for 'she is' is 'Yes, she is'.

items.prompt: What is the nationality for Italy?
items.explanation: Italian is the nationality for people from Italy.

items.prompt: Are you and Paul British? No, we ______.
items.explanation: 'Aren't' is the contraction of 'are not', used with 'we'.

items.prompt: Where ______ the offices located?
items.explanation: The offices (they) is plural, so we use 'are'.

items.prompt: He is from China. He is ______.
items.explanation: Chinese is the correct nationality for China.

items.prompt: I ______ Australian. I am Canadian.
items.explanation: 'm not is the contraction for 'am not'.

items.prompt: ______ your passport valid?
items.explanation: Your passport (it) is singular, so we use 'Is'.

items.prompt: What is the nationality for Brazil?
items.explanation: Brazilian is the nationality for Brazil.

items.prompt: Are they from Portugal? Yes, they ______.
items.explanation: Short affirmative answer for 'they are' is 'Yes, they are'.

items.prompt: She is from the USA. She is ______.
items.explanation: American is the nationality for the USA.

items.prompt: We ______ late for the meeting.
items.explanation: We use 'aren't' with 'we'.

items.prompt: Is Lisbon in Spain? No, it ______.
items.explanation: Lisbon (it) takes the negative singular form 'isn't'.

items.prompt: What is the nationality for Turkey?
items.explanation: Turkish is the nationality for Turkey.

items.prompt: ______ the manager from India?
items.explanation: The manager (he/she) is singular, so we use 'Is'.

items.prompt: They are from Greece. They are ______.
items.explanation: Greek is the nationality for Greece.

items.prompt: I ______ a student. I am a manager.
items.explanation: With 'I', we use 'am not' or the contraction ''m not'.

items.prompt: Are we ready? Yes, we ______.
items.explanation: Short affirmative answer for 'we are' is 'Yes, we are'.

items.prompt: What is the nationality for Egypt?
items.explanation: Egyptian is the nationality for Egypt.

items.prompt: Is Moscow the capital of Russia? Yes, it ______.
items.explanation: Short affirmative answer for 'it is' is 'Yes, it is'.

items.text: Where [are] you from?
items.explanation: We use 'are' with 'you' in questions.

items.text: I [am] not from China; I am from Japan.
items.explanation: With 'I', the verb to be is 'am'.

items.text: She is from Paris. She is [French].
items.explanation: French is the nationality for someone from France.

items.text: [Is] your colleague from Germany?
items.explanation: We use 'Is' for singular subjects (your colleague) in questions.

items.text: They [are] not Italian; they are Spanish.
items.explanation: With 'They', the verb to be is 'are'.

items.text: He is from Toronto. He is [Canadian].
items.explanation: Canadian is the nationality for Canada.

items.text: Are you a manager? No, I [am] not.
items.explanation: Short negative answer for 'I am' is 'No, I am not'.

items.text: London [is] not the capital of Scotland.
items.explanation: London (it) takes the singular verb 'is'.

items.text: We are from Mexico City. We are [Mexican].
items.explanation: Mexican is the nationality for Mexico.

items.text: [Are] the documents in the folder?
items.explanation: The documents (they) is plural, so we use 'Are' in questions.

items.text: My parents [are] not from Europe.
items.explanation: My parents (they) is plural, so we use 'are'.

items.text: Is he from London? No, he [is] not.
items.explanation: Short negative answer for 'he is' is 'No, he is not'.

items.text: I am from New Delhi. I am [Indian].
items.explanation: Indian is the nationality for India.

items.text: You [are] not in my team.
items.explanation: With 'You', we use 'are'.

items.text: Is the company American? Yes, it [is].
items.explanation: Short affirmative answer for 'it is' is 'Yes, it is'.

items.title: International Colleagues
items.text: My name is John. I am from London, in the United Kingdom. I am British. I work for a large international company. My colleagues are from different countries. Maria is from Rome, she is Italian. Hans is from Berlin, he is German. We are not in the same department, but we work together on some projects.

vocabulary.definition: Involving two or more nations.
People you work with.

questions.question: Are they all in the same department?

items.explanation: Understanding origins and professional relationships in a text.

items.title: Meeting a Client
items.text: Hello! I'm Sarah. I'm from New York. I'm not a manager; I'm an assistant. This is my friend, Pedro. He isn't from the USA. He is from Madrid, so he is Spanish. We are in a meeting right now with a client from Japan. The client is Japanese.

vocabulary.definition: A person who helps someone in their job.
A person or organization using the services of a professional person or company.

questions.question: What is the nationality of the client?

items.explanation: Extracting job titles and nationalities from a dialogue summary.

items.title: Diverse Leadership
items.text: The company 'TechWorld' is based in California, USA. However, the CEO, Mr. Tanaka, is not American. He is from Tokyo, Japan. The marketing director, Ms. Schmidt, is from Frankfurt, Germany. They have offices in five different countries. The company is very diverse.

vocabulary.definition: Located in a specific place.
Showing a great deal of variety; very different.

items.explanation: Identifying leadership origins in a corporate context.

items.title: Airport Control
items.text: Passport control is busy at the airport. Officer: 'Are you from the UK?' Passenger: 'No, I'm not. I'm from Ireland. I'm Irish.' Officer: 'Is your wife from Ireland too?' Passenger: 'No, she isn't. She's from France. She's French.' Officer: 'Thank you. Have a nice flight.'

vocabulary.definition: Having a lot of things to do or a lot of people.
A journey in an aircraft.

questions.question: Is the passenger from the UK?

items.explanation: Comprehending a dialogue about travel and nationality.

items.title: New Hires
items.text: Three new employees started today. Ahmed is from Egypt, so he is Egyptian. Lin is from China, so she is Chinese. Carlos is from Brazil, so he is Brazilian. They are not in the office today; they are at a training center in the city center.

vocabulary.definition: People who work for a company.
A place where people learn skills for their job.

questions.question: Are they in the office today?

items.explanation: Tracking locations and nationalities of new staff.

items.title: Global Partners
items.text: This is a map of our global partners. Our partner in Lisbon is Portuguese. Our partner in Athens is Greek. Our partner in Warsaw is Polish. We are not a small company; we have partners all over Europe.

vocabulary.definition: Relating to the whole world.
People or companies that work together.

questions.question: Where is the Greek partner located?

items.explanation: Identifying locations of international business partners.

items.title: Australian Company
items.text: Are you interested in our products? We are an Australian company based in Sydney. Our products are popular in Asia and Europe. We are not very old, we started only two years ago. Our team is very energetic and international.

vocabulary.definition: Liked by many people.
Showing or involving great activity or vitality.

questions.question: Is the company old?
options: No, it's only two years old

items.explanation: Determining age and location of a business from its description.

items.title: Management Abroad
items.text: My manager, Mr. Rossi, is Italian. He is from Milan. He is very strict but fair. He is not in the office today because he is at a conference in Switzerland. The conference is in Zurich. He returns on Wednesday.

vocabulary.definition: Demanding that rules concerning behavior are obeyed.
Treating people equally without favoritism or discrimination.

items.explanation: Understanding a manager's temporary location and origin.

items.title: Visitor Engineers
items.text: We have two visitors today. Mr. Kim and Mr. Park. They are from South Korea. They are Korean. They are not here for a meeting; they are here for a site visit. They are engineers. They stay in a hotel near the factory.

vocabulary.definition: People who visit a person or place.
A building where goods are manufactured or assembled.

items.explanation: Identifying roles and nationalities of guests.

items.title: Employee ID Form
items.text: This is a form for a new ID card. Name: Sofia Lopez. Origin: Mexico. Nationality: Mexican. Job: Receptionist. Department: Administration. Status: Not a permanent employee (Trainee). Valid until: December 2025.

vocabulary.definition: A person undergoing training for a particular job or profession.
Legally or officially acceptable.

items.explanation: Interpreting professional information from a form.
